Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A casual conversation drifts toward personal topics but nothing particularly sensitive is mentioned.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow, glancing at the clock on the wall of the break room. Two minutes until the safety briefing—mandatory, no exceptions. The foreman had made it clear: everyone needed to be there, on time, ready to listen. As a construction laborer, I knew the importance of sticking to protocols and being a reliable part of the crew. But just as I was about to head out, my phone buzzed. It was a message from one of the people I volunteer with at the shelter, someone who rarely reached out. I answered, and our conversation drifted into personal territory—not anything sensitive, but I could sense they needed to talk. I felt torn. The team was counting on me to be present and focused, but as a volunteer, I was expected to respect and support the people I helped, especially when they reached out. My heart pounded as I stood in the doorway, caught between the demands of the site and the quiet trust of someone in need.
